results.summary:
Summary of agreement, conflicts, and recommended synthesis with prioritized next actions.

Context note: Cycle 12, Divergence Score 0.87 — branches share core themes but have meaningful differences about scope, speed, and product mix. Below I highlight where they align, where they conflict, and a practical blended path you can execute in ~12 months.

1) Areas of agreement
- Electrification is an existential threat to pure ICE revenue but also creates opportunities for higher-margin services (EV conversions, battery services, hybrid support).
- Shops must re-skill staff for high-voltage systems, battery diagnostics, and EV-specific service protocols.
- A mixed business model (retain ICE work while adding EV/hybrid services and conversion offerings) is the preferred way to hedge risk and capture new revenue.
- Certification, safety, tooling, and documented processes are essential before doing EV work at scale.
- There is a market for classic-car electrification and “authentic-feel” retrofits that command premium pricing from collectors and buyers seeking modern drivability.
- Partnerships (battery suppliers/repairers, converters, insurers) reduce technical and capital barriers.

2) Conflicting points (and practical implications)
- Scope of pivot vs. speed:
  - Branch 1 implies a broad, deep reskilling for general EV maintenance (longer timeline, heavy investment).
  - Branch 3 pushes for a fast 12-month pivot toward targeted EV work (rapid, focused investments).
  - Implication: You can’t simultaneously become a full-service EV dealer and run a fast, low-capex pivot. Choose focused offerings first.
- Product focus: full EV conversions vs. hybrid/ICE-preservation:
  - Branch 2 emphasizes preserving heritage authenticity with hybrid/ICE maintenance + turnkey conversions that balance authenticity and modern drivability.
  - Branch 1/3 suggest charging into EV conversions and battery services (more radical departures from ICE).
  - Implication: Some customers want reversible/minimally invasive solutions. A one-size-fits-all conversion approach risks alienating preservation-minded clients.
- Capital/time for tooling and certification vs. immediate revenue:
  - Doing safe, certified EV work requires tooling, PPE, and training—this delays revenue. Branch 3’s fast pivot assumes low-cost entry points (e.g., partnerships or subcontracting) that may reduce margin/control.
  - Implication: Use partnerships and staged purchases to get started quickly while investing in core capabilities over time.

3) Recommended synthesis and prioritized next actions (practical, phased plan)

Aim: Become a hybrid shop that preserves ICE business while building a premium EV-conversion and battery-services niche — start lean, prove market fit, then scale.

Phase 0 — Immediate (0–30 days)
- Safety & compliance: Draft an EV safety plan; purchase basic PPE (insulated gloves, mats) and post HV safety signage. Stop work on HV systems until basic training completed.
- Market validation: Audit your customer base + local collector clubs; list 10 prospective conversion/restoration leads. Estimate local demand and willingness to pay.
- Partnerships: Contact 1–2 battery refurbishers/salvage yards and an experienced conversion shop for mentoring/subcontracting. Begin conversations with local parts suppliers (inverters, motor kits).

Phase 1 — Quick-start (1–3 months)
- Training: Send 1–2 techs to an EV safety + high-voltage fundamentals course (ASE L3 or manufacturer EV basics, or equivalent). Online + 1-day hands-on EV safety courses are fastest.
- Focus offerings: Launch 2–3 narrow, marketable service lines:
  1) EV conversion consultation + feasibility packages (paid diagnostic, project quote).
  2) Reversible/bolt-in conversions for classic cars (keep original drivetrain for authenticity or provide swap-back option).
  3) Battery diagnostics & replacement sourcing for hybrids/plug-in models (partnered or subcontracted initially).
- Tooling (minimal): Basic multimeter with HV probes, clamp meter, insulation tester, battery service tools, basic junction-box fabrication kit. Budget to avoid large inverter/charger inventory yet.
- Pricing model: Fixed-price conversion tiers (e.g., “Street Tourer” bolt-in, “Restorer” reversible, “Full EV” bespoke) with clear scope; diagnostic fee credited to project if accepted. Use value-based pricing for collector market (premium for authenticity preservation).

Phase 2 — Build capability (3–9 months)
- Deep training & certification: ASE EV certifications and manufacturer training where possible. Cross-train technicians in battery pack repair, BMS basics, and EV controls.
- Tooling & shop upgrades: HV insulation testers, battery lift/stands, lift-rated rigging, vacuum/evap handling (if doing hybrids), OBD/EV-specific scan tools, torque tooling for high-current connectors.
- Pilot projects: Execute 1–3 paid conversions/retrofits as showcase builds. Document all processes, timesheets, parts lists, and before/after media for marketing.
- Service bundles: Create maintenance bundles for hybrid/ICE owners (annual HV safety check, battery conditioning, software updates) and subscription-style battery-warranty/maintenance packages (Battery-as-a-Service options with partner).
- Warranty & insurance: Update shop insurance and offer clear warranties; consult legal on liabilities for conversions.

Phase 3 — Scale & refine (9–12 months)
- Expand offerings based on pilots: Add full conversions, hybrid retention packages, or preservation-focused retrofits depending on demand.
- Hire/retain: If demand justifies, hire/upgrade 1–2 techs with EV experience.
- Pricing refinement: Move to margin-based pricing for conversions, and recurring revenue models for battery maintenance and warranties.
- Marketing: Showcase case studies to collector communities, classic-car shows, and local EV owner groups. Offer demo drives and transparent technical documentation to build trust.
- Strategic partnerships: Formalize battery-swap/repair partnerships or white-label battery-as-a-service agreements.

Concrete deliverables for your next 90 days (highest ROI)
- Complete HV safety training for at least one lead tech.
- Close at least one battery-partner relationship and one mentor/subcontractor conversion shop.
- Publish 2 fixed-tier conversion packages with clear scope & pricing on your website.
- Run one paid pilot conversion or hybrid service bundle; capture media and customer testimonials.
- Acquire essential HV PPE and one insulation tester / HV multimeter.

Trade-offs & pricing guidance
- Conversion pricing: Base packages + options. Example tiers (illustrative): Bolt-in street kit $15–30k, Reversible restorer $25–45k, Full bespoke conversion $50k+. Price by labor hours + parts + margin + warranty risk buffer.
- Recurring revenue: Battery maintenance subscriptions (e.g., $300–1,200/year) and extended warranties on conversions (price to reflect expected battery lifecycle and partner terms).
- Margin management: Early work may have lower margins due to learning curve—price to cover warranty reserves and partner fees.

Risks and mitigations
- Liability for HV work — mitigate with training, PPE, documented SOPs, and insurer notification.
- Supply chain volatility for batteries/components — hold few high-turn items, rely on vetted suppliers, and disclose lead times.
- Reputation risk for poor conversions — do pilot projects, document processes, and offer limited warranties during ramp phase.

Quick checklist for deciding focus (answer these to choose your initial product mix)
- Do local collectors prioritize authenticity (retain engine) or drivability (full EV)? If authenticity — prioritize reversible/hybrid kits. If drivability — offer full conversions.
- Can you secure a battery/repair partner quickly? If yes — accelerate battery-services and subscription models.
- Do you have 1–2 techs willing to certify and lead EV work? If no — rely on subcontracting/partnerships until you can train.

Bottom line recommendation
Start targeted and staged: retain ICE repair revenue, launch narrow EV conversion and battery services via partnerships and paid pilot builds, train core techs for high-voltage safety first, and scale tooling/certifications after you validate demand. This hedges risk, captures premium collector business, and puts you on a clear 12-month path to profitable EV work.
